Award.AwardTitle: Creating a National Higher Education Rating System for STEM Equality Achievement (SEA): The SEA Change Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The STEM Equity Achievement (SEA Change) workshop project will bring together teams from six to eight public and private higher education institutions to develop and launch a pilot program to recognize U.S. institutions higher education that have demonstrated commitments to promoting an equitable environment for underrepresented groups in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics). The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) is a partner on this pilot project with the institutions of higher education. The model to be developed will be informed by the successful Athena SWAN model developed in the United Kingdom (UK). Athena SWAN evolved from work between the Athena Project and the Scientific Women's Academic Network (SWAN) which were earlier efforts to advance the representation of women in science, technology, engineering, medicine and mathematics in the UK.

The SEA Change workshop supported with this grant is expected to result in a rating model that the participating institutions will implement and test as a pilot. This pilot work will develop and refine a process and structure for a rating system that may be effective in the United States. Based on the success in the UK, this type of rating system could result in institutions of higher education voluntarily seeking ratings from the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
University of Massachusetts Lowell, Boston University, and AAAS received an initial grant from NSF in March 2016 to host a workshop to lay the groundwork for the SEA Change program.  The NSF grant recognized the need for a national transformative project to advance equal opportunities in STEM fields regardless of gender identification, race/ ethnicity or disability status. SEA Change, modeled on the earlier Athena/SWAN initiative in the United Kingdom, has taken up the challenge of producing a compelling and effective self-driven, metric-based system for promoting institutional change in higher education to achieve equity and sustainable transformation.  As an outcome of the enthusiastic response from this NSF workshop and follow on efforts, SEA Change is now hosted by the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), the world’s largest international, nonprofit scientific association.  AAAS has worked for decades to support equity, diversity, and inclusion in science, technology, engineering, medicine, and mathematics (STEM). AAAS joins other nations collaborating in an international network with ECU to implement an equity self-assessment and improvement framework in higher education, expanding from the UK into the Republic of Ireland and Australia, and now into the US and Canada

 

Specifically  the NSF grant has supported the following important outcomes:

1. Working Conference in Spring 2016 : Introduced SEA Change Mission and Goals to potential Pilot Program participants from public sector and private sector higher education institutions


2.  Defining Metrics and Processes: Core group of early participant institutions were joined by STEM Professional Organizations to develop data metrics to drive transformative change in systemic and sustainable pathways

3. New England Regional Meetings in 2017 and 2018:  Created regional network of interested public and private sector higher education institutions to collaborate on common areas which challenge attainment of equity goals and on existing programs which address possibilities for change


4. Outreach and dissemination:  The PI/co-PIs (Dr. Shirley Malcolm, AAAS; Professor Joyce Wong, Boston University; Professor Paula Rayman and Professor Julie Chen, UMass Lowell) traveled to conferences and workshops in the United States and internationally to invite discussion of the mission and goals of SEA Change, raise national and global awareness of the need for transformative change so no talent is left behind in STEM fields and to increase comparative perspectives on what works to overcome resistance to institutional change.

 

In February 2019 it is expected that the first Bronze Awards (the first stage of mapping directions for institutional change) will be announced at the Annual AAAS Meetings at a session led by Dr. Shirley Malcom, AAAS.
